channel.title: Global News Podcast
channel.description: The day’s top stories from BBC News. Delivered twice a day on weekdays, daily at weekends
channel.itunes:summary: The day’s top stories from BBC News. Delivered twice a day on weekdays, daily at weekends
channel.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Rwanda closes part of the Congolese border over Ebola outbreak
item.description: Measure comes as 2 deaths from the disease are confirmed in Goma, also: attack on military parade in Yemeni city of Aden kills 30, and how effective can the Dutch burka ban be?
item.itunes:subtitle: The measure comes as 2 death from the disease are confirmed in Goma
item.itunes:summary: Measure comes as 2 deaths from the disease are confirmed in Goma, also: attack on military parade in Yemeni city of Aden kills 30, and how effective can the Dutch burka ban be?
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: US sanctions Iran's foreign minister Zarif
item.description: The sanctions freeze any assets of Mohammed Javad Zarif in America, or controlled by US entities. Also: a second person has died of Ebola in eastern Congo, and will the threatened vaquita porpoise survive?
item.itunes:subtitle: Mr Zarif will still be able to travel to New York on official UN business
item.itunes:summary: The sanctions freeze any assets of Mohammed Javad Zarif in America, or controlled by US entities. Also: a second person has died of Ebola in eastern Congo, and will the threatened vaquita porpoise survive?
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: US Democratic presidential hopefuls clash over ways to topple Trump
item.description: Healthcare was on the agenda as the first group of Democratic candidates debated in Detroit. Also: all schools in Sudan have been closed following demonstrations over the death of students at an earlier rally, and the pretty Austrian village that is being overrun by tourists.
item.itunes:subtitle: Healthcare was the focal point in the debate.
item.itunes:summary: Healthcare was on the agenda as the first group of Democratic candidates debated in Detroit. Also: all schools in Sudan have been closed following demonstrations over the death of students at an earlier rally, and the pretty Austrian village that is being overrun by tourists.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Protests as Trump marks Jamestown democracy anniversary
item.description: President Trump took part in events at the historical settlement of Jamestown in Virginia, marking the four hundredth anniversary of the birth of democracy in America. Also: 'World shrugging' as Syria death toll mounts, and ear 'tickling' therapy could 'help thwart ageing'.
item.itunes:subtitle: One local politician held a sign reading "Deport hate"
item.itunes:summary: President Trump took part in events at the historical settlement of Jamestown in Virginia, marking the four hundredth anniversary of the birth of democracy in America. Also: 'World shrugging' as Syria death toll mounts, and ear 'tickling' therapy could 'help thwart ageing'.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: China says 're-educated' Uighurs released home
item.description: Up to a million ethnic Uighurs and other Muslims are believed to have been detained in the camps for months, or years, without trial. The ruler of Dubai ruler and his estranged wife begin a London court battle. Plus in Sweden the American rapper ASAP Rocky has appeared in court, pleading not guilty to assault.
item.itunes:subtitle: The claim hasn't been independently verified
item.itunes:summary: Up to a million ethnic Uighurs and other Muslims are believed to have been detained in the camps for months, or years, without trial. The ruler of Dubai ruler and his estranged wife begin a London court battle. Plus in Sweden the American rapper ASAP Rocky has appeared in court, pleading not guilty to assault.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Brazil jail riot leaves scores dead
item.description: Officials say a fight between rival gangs in the northern Brazilian prison lasted five hours. Also: outrage as high school students shot dead in Sudan, and India tiger census shows rapid population growth.
item.itunes:subtitle: The authorities denied the prison was overcrowded
item.itunes:summary: Officials say a fight between rival gangs in the northern Brazilian prison lasted five hours. Also: outrage as high school students shot dead in Sudan, and India tiger census shows rapid population growth.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: China condemns 'horrendous' Hong Kong protests
item.description: The city has seen eight consecutive weekends of anti-government protests. In India, an investigation is underway after a teenager who's accused a politician of rape is seriously injured in a road accident. And we'll explain why some are calling today 'Earth Overshoot Day'.
item.itunes:subtitle: Beijing blamed unrest on radicals and 'irresponsible figures' in the West
item.itunes:summary: The city has seen eight consecutive weekends of anti-government protests. In India, an investigation is underway after a teenager who's accused a politician of rape is seriously injured in a road accident. And we'll explain why some are calling today 'Earth Overshoot Day'.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Dan Coats US intelligence chief to 'step down'
item.description: Dan Coats is leaving office after clashing with President Trump on national security. Also, dozens of mourners 'killed by Boko Haram' at a funeral in north Nigeria. And Brazil miners kill tribal leader in Amazon land invasion.
item.itunes:subtitle: Dan Coats is leaving office after clashing with President Trump on national security
item.itunes:summary: Dan Coats is leaving office after clashing with President Trump on national security. Also, dozens of mourners 'killed by Boko Haram' at a funeral in north Nigeria. And Brazil miners kill tribal leader in Amazon land invasion.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Outrage at Trump's remarks about black Congressman
item.description: Mr Trump called Elijah Cummings a 'brutal bully', and his district a 'rat infested mess'. Mr Cummings had criticised conditions in migrant detention centres. Also: Russian police detain more than a thousand activists and the joke of the Roman pen.
item.itunes:subtitle: Mr Trump called Elijah Cummings a 'brutal bully', and his district a 'rat infested mess'
item.itunes:summary: Mr Trump called Elijah Cummings a 'brutal bully', and his district a 'rat infested mess'. Mr Cummings had criticised conditions in migrant detention centres. Also: Russian police detain more than a thousand activists and the joke of the Roman pen.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Guatemala agrees to US migration deal
item.description: The agreement will force thousands of Central American migrants to seek asylum in Guatemala instead of the US. Also, pro-democracy demonstrations last late into the night at Hong Kong’s airport. And Russians are urging their government to act, as hundreds of forest fires tear through the Arctic.
item.itunes:subtitle: Migrants bound for US must now seek asylum in Guatemala instead
item.itunes:summary: The agreement will force thousands of Central American migrants to seek asylum in Guatemala instead of the US. Also, pro-democracy demonstrations last late into the night at Hong Kong’s airport. And Russians are urging their government to act, as hundreds of forest fires tear through the Arctic.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Syria war: UN criticises 'apparent international indifference' as civilians are killed
item.description:
UN human rights chief says over 100 people died in government attacks in past 10 days. Michelle Bachelet criticised the 'failure of leadership by the world's most powerful nations'.
Also, pro-democracy protestors hold sit-in at Hong Kong's international airport, and a young Rwandan man walks across his country - to raise awareness of the 1994 genocide.
item.itunes:subtitle: UN human rights chief says over 100 people died in government attacks in past 10 days
item.itunes:summary:
UN human rights chief says over 100 people died in government attacks in past 10 days. Michelle Bachelet criticised the 'failure of leadership by the world's most powerful nations'.
Also, pro-democracy protestors hold sit-in at Hong Kong's international airport, and a young Rwandan man walks across his country - to raise awareness of the 1994 genocide.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: New refugee tragedy off the coast of Libya
item.description: Migrant boat with 300 people aboard sinks attempting crossing to Europe. Initial reports say as many as one hundred and fifty people died -- though the final figure remains unclear. Also: Europe swelters, the US government announces the return of the death penalty for federal crimes, and the threat of annihilation facing Kenya’s donkeys.
item.itunes:subtitle: Migrant boat with 300 people aboard sinks attempting crossing to Europe
item.itunes:summary: Migrant boat with 300 people aboard sinks attempting crossing to Europe. Initial reports say as many as one hundred and fifty people died -- though the final figure remains unclear. Also: Europe swelters, the US government announces the return of the death penalty for federal crimes, and the threat of annihilation facing Kenya’s donkeys.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Europe: second heatwave breaks high-temperature records
item.description:
Much of northern Europe swelters as second heatwave in one month reaches its peak. Highest-temperature records broken in UK, France, Germany and Netherlands.
Also, Britain's new Prime Minister Boris Johnson promises "beginning of a golden age", and French inventor fails in attempt to cross English Channel on jet-powered flyboard.
item.itunes:subtitle: Much of northern Europe swelters as second heatwave in one month reaches its peak
item.itunes:summary:
Much of northern Europe swelters as second heatwave in one month reaches its peak. Highest-temperature records broken in UK, France, Germany and Netherlands.
Also, Britain's new Prime Minister Boris Johnson promises "beginning of a golden age", and French inventor fails in attempt to cross English Channel on jet-powered flyboard.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: New British PM Boris Johnson overhauls cabinet
item.description: Mr Johnson has given senior positions to fellow Brexiteers. Also: Facebook's five billion dollar fine for violating consumer privacy, and Lapland's indigenous people under threat.
item.itunes:subtitle: Mr Johnson has given senior positions to fellow Brexiteers
item.itunes:summary: Mr Johnson has given senior positions to fellow Brexiteers. Also: Facebook's five billion dollar fine for violating consumer privacy, and Lapland's indigenous people under threat.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: UK leadership handover
item.description: She hands over the reins of power to her successor, Boris Johnson, along with the keys to Number 10 Downing Street. Later, Mr Johnson will announce his most senior cabinet appointments. In the US the former special counsel Robert Mueller is testifying before Congress on his report on Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election.
item.itunes:subtitle: Theresa May has taken her last Prime Minister's Questions in Parliament
item.itunes:summary: She hands over the reins of power to her successor, Boris Johnson, along with the keys to Number 10 Downing Street. Later, Mr Johnson will announce his most senior cabinet appointments. In the US the former special counsel Robert Mueller is testifying before Congress on his report on Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Brexit challenges for Britain's new PM
item.description: We hear about Boris Johnson from the people who know him best as European leaders and members of his own party warn of difficulties ahead. Also: A Gambian soldier has admitted involvement in the killing of about fifty African migrants on the orders of the former president and scientists warn that the next 18 months will be a crucial period for dealing with global warming.
item.itunes:subtitle: We hear about Boris Johnson from the people who know him best
item.itunes:summary: We hear about Boris Johnson from the people who know him best as European leaders and members of his own party warn of difficulties ahead. Also: A Gambian soldier has admitted involvement in the killing of about fifty African migrants on the orders of the former president and scientists warn that the next 18 months will be a crucial period for dealing with global warming.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Boris Johnson wins race to be British Prime Minister
item.description: The former London mayor takes over from Theresa May on Wednesday. Also: South Korea fires warning shots at a Russian aircraft after an alleged airspace violation, and the young married couples in India spending big to go viral on the internet with unique wedding photos.
item.itunes:subtitle: Boris Johnson has been elected new Conservative leader and will become the next UK leader
item.itunes:summary: The former London mayor takes over from Theresa May on Wednesday. Also: South Korea fires warning shots at a Russian aircraft after an alleged airspace violation, and the young married couples in India spending big to go viral on the internet with unique wedding photos.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Iran tanker seizure: UK seeks European help on Gulf shipping
item.description: Iran’s detention of a tanker is being labelled an act of ‘state piracy’. Also: Huge crowds have gathered in the US territory of Puerto Rico, demanding the immediate resignation of the governor, and India launches its much-anticipated second moon mission.
item.itunes:subtitle: British Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt is calling for the release of a British ship
item.itunes:summary: Iran’s detention of a tanker is being labelled an act of ‘state piracy’. Also: Huge crowds have gathered in the US territory of Puerto Rico, demanding the immediate resignation of the governor, and India launches its much-anticipated second moon mission.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Hong Kong protests: armed mob violence leaves city in shock
item.description: Dozens of masked men storm a train station and assault pro-democracy protesters, meanwhile the authorities in Beijing and Hong Kong condemn an attack on China's liaison office in the territory, as a challenge to the nation's sovereignty. Also: Kenya's finance minister, Henry Rotich, has been arrested following corruption allegations, and mystery surrounds stressed cows in eastern France - but could it be down to the presence of nearby windfarms?
item.itunes:subtitle: Dozens of masked men storm a train station and assault pro-democracy protesters
item.itunes:summary: Dozens of masked men storm a train station and assault pro-democracy protesters, meanwhile the authorities in Beijing and Hong Kong condemn an attack on China's liaison office in the territory, as a challenge to the nation's sovereignty. Also: Kenya's finance minister, Henry Rotich, has been arrested following corruption allegations, and mystery surrounds stressed cows in eastern France - but could it be down to the presence of nearby windfarms?
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: President Zelensky well ahead of his rivals in Ukrainian elections
item.description: The comedian who swept to power three months ago has invited another political novice, Ukraine's best known rock star, for talks on forming a coalition. Also, clashes in Hong Kong as pro-democracy protesters march on Beijing's headquarters in the territory. And just days before Britain gets a new prime minister the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Philip Hammond, goes on live TV to announce he's ready to resign over Brexit.
item.itunes:subtitle: Exit polls suggest the former comedian will fall short of a majority
item.itunes:summary: The comedian who swept to power three months ago has invited another political novice, Ukraine's best known rock star, for talks on forming a coalition. Also, clashes in Hong Kong as pro-democracy protesters march on Beijing's headquarters in the territory. And just days before Britain gets a new prime minister the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Philip Hammond, goes on live TV to announce he's ready to resign over Brexit.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Moon Landing Special
item.description: Fifty years since men first walked on the Moon, we celebrate the Apollo 11 mission. Also: we assess its impact on politics and culture and ponder the future of space exploration.
item.itunes:subtitle: Fifty years since men first walked on the Moon, we celebrate the Apollo 11 mission
item.itunes:summary: Fifty years since men first walked on the Moon, we celebrate the Apollo 11 mission. Also: we assess its impact on politics and culture and ponder the future of space exploration.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: The UK condemns Iran after guards seize a British oil tanker
item.description: Britain's Foreign Secretary, Jeremy Hunt, has denounced as "completely unacceptable" the capture of the ship and he said there would be serious consequences if it wasn't released. Also: the Kosovan prime minister has resigned after being called for questioning as a war crimes suspect and a warning from Youtube over regulation.
item.itunes:subtitle: The ship, Stena Impero, was forced to divert into Iranian waters
item.itunes:summary: Britain's Foreign Secretary, Jeremy Hunt, has denounced as "completely unacceptable" the capture of the ship and he said there would be serious consequences if it wasn't released. Also: the Kosovan prime minister has resigned after being called for questioning as a war crimes suspect and a warning from Youtube over regulation.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Srebrenica massacre: Dutch state was '10% liable' for 350 deaths
item.description:
Dutch supreme court says Netherlands partially responsible for deaths of Bosnian Muslims. Dutch troops had been guarding a UN safe zone in 1995 when it was overrun by Bosnian Serbs.
Also, Saudi Arabia urges respect for Islamic law after Western singers perform in Jeddah, and how a man in Assam found a tiger resting on his bed.
item.itunes:subtitle: Dutch supreme court says Netherlands partially responsible for deaths of Bosnian Muslims
item.itunes:summary:
Dutch supreme court says Netherlands partially responsible for deaths of Bosnian Muslims. Dutch troops had been guarding a UN safe zone in 1995 when it was overrun by Bosnian Serbs.
Also, Saudi Arabia urges respect for Islamic law after Western singers perform in Jeddah, and how a man in Assam found a tiger resting on his bed.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Brexit: MPs back bid to block Parliament suspension
item.description: A majority of 41 MPs approved the amendment to block the suspension of Parliament. The move is to prevent the future Prime Minister forcing through a no-deal Brexit. Also: President Trump says the US has shot down an Iranian drone threatening an American warship in the Gulf, and we report on the Swiss wine festival that only happens a few times a century.
item.itunes:subtitle: The move is to prevent the next Prime Minister forcing through a no-deal Brexit
item.itunes:summary: A majority of 41 MPs approved the amendment to block the suspension of Parliament. The move is to prevent the future Prime Minister forcing through a no-deal Brexit. Also: President Trump says the US has shot down an Iranian drone threatening an American warship in the Gulf, and we report on the Swiss wine festival that only happens a few times a century.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Japan: Arson attack at Kyoto anime studio kills 33
item.description:
At least 33 dead and dozens injured after man sets fire to an animation studio. Police say a 41-year-old suspect broke into the building and sprayed petrol before igniting it.
Also, new warnings to the UK about potential dangers posed by a 'no deal' Brexit, and how a South African taxi-driver revealed his talent as an opera-singer.
item.itunes:subtitle: At least 33 dead and dozens injured after man sets fire to an animation studio
item.itunes:summary:
At least 33 dead and dozens injured after man sets fire to an animation studio. Police say a 41-year-old suspect broke into the building and sprayed petrol before igniting it.
Also, new warnings to the UK about potential dangers posed by a 'no deal' Brexit, and how a South African taxi-driver revealed his talent as an opera-singer.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: El Chapo trial: Mexican drug lord gets life
item.description: He is a former head of the Sinaloa cartel, which officials say was the biggest supplier of drugs to the US. The World Health Organization has declared the Ebola crisis in eastern Congo a public health emergency, and the dragon with a lethal bite that tourists can’t stay away from.
item.itunes:subtitle: A US judge has sentenced Mexican drug kingpin Joaquín "El Chapo" Guzmán to life in prison
item.itunes:summary: He is a former head of the Sinaloa cartel, which officials say was the biggest supplier of drugs to the US. The World Health Organization has declared the Ebola crisis in eastern Congo a public health emergency, and the dragon with a lethal bite that tourists can’t stay away from.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Sudan: Military and civilians sign deal to end deadly turmoil
item.description:
Ruling military council and opposition leaders have signed a power-sharing accord. Sudan has been in chaos since the military ousted President Omar al-Bashir in April.
Also, a surprise as Turkish court acquits two journalists and a human rights activist of terrorism charges, and Andrea Camilleri - author of the "Inspector Montalbano" stories - has died aged 93.
item.itunes:subtitle: Ruling military council and opposition leaders have signed a power-sharing accord
item.itunes:summary:
Ruling military council and opposition leaders have signed a power-sharing accord. Sudan has been in chaos since the military ousted President Omar al-Bashir in April.
Also, a surprise as Turkish court acquits two journalists and a human rights activist of terrorism charges, and Andrea Camilleri - author of the "Inspector Montalbano" stories - has died aged 93.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Five decades since first Moon landing mission
item.description: Fifty years since launch of Apollo Eleven mission - those involved remember; European Parliament narrowly approves next European Commission President; Dozens killed in monsoon flooding in South Asia - millions are displaced.
item.itunes:subtitle: Fifty years since launch of Apollo Eleven mission - those involved remember.
item.itunes:summary: Fifty years since launch of Apollo Eleven mission - those involved remember; European Parliament narrowly approves next European Commission President; Dozens killed in monsoon flooding in South Asia - millions are displaced.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: The German defence minister, Ursula von der Leyen, bids for the presidency of the EU Commission
item.description: Mrs von der Leyen said dealing with climate change and tackling illegal immigration humanely would be her priorities. Also: on the second day of his appearance before a corruption inquiry, the former South African President Jacob Zuma said he'd received a death threat; and events take place to commemorate the fiftieth anniversary of the Apollo Eleven mission to the Moon.
item.itunes:subtitle: Mrs von der Leyen outlined her priorities to MEPs.
item.itunes:summary: Mrs von der Leyen said dealing with climate change and tackling illegal immigration humanely would be her priorities. Also: on the second day of his appearance before a corruption inquiry, the former South African President Jacob Zuma said he'd received a death threat; and events take place to commemorate the fiftieth anniversary of the Apollo Eleven mission to the Moon.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Trump tweet row: Four congresswomen accuse president of distraction tactics
item.description: The four US congresswomen attacked by US President Donald Trump in a series of racially charged tweets have dismissed his remarks. Also: A new study has found that anorexia isn't only a mental illness, but can be caused by a physical predisposition, and the tiny monkey fossil that’s a game changer for evolutionary scientists.
item.itunes:subtitle: Representatives urged the US people "not to take the bait”
item.itunes:summary: The four US congresswomen attacked by US President Donald Trump in a series of racially charged tweets have dismissed his remarks. Also: A new study has found that anorexia isn't only a mental illness, but can be caused by a physical predisposition, and the tiny monkey fossil that’s a game changer for evolutionary scientists.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: South Africa: Ex-president Zuma responds to corruption allegations
item.description: Jacob Zuma, who stepped down last year amid claims of illegal financial gain, has begun testifying at a judicial inquiry. Also: Hong Kong’s chief of police condemns pro-democracy protesters as “thugs”. And the family of Neil Armstrong look back at the life of the first man to set foot on the moon.
item.itunes:subtitle: Jacob Zuma tells a commission that the accusations are “character assassination”
item.itunes:summary: Jacob Zuma, who stepped down last year amid claims of illegal financial gain, has begun testifying at a judicial inquiry. Also: Hong Kong’s chief of police condemns pro-democracy protesters as “thugs”. And the family of Neil Armstrong look back at the life of the first man to set foot on the moon.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Trump accused of racism over tweets against congresswomen
item.description: President Trump claimed the women "originally came from countries whose governments are a complete and total catastrophe". Also: Champs-Elysees clashes after Bastille Day parade, and Djokovic beats Federer in Wimbledon tennis epic.
item.itunes:subtitle: Mr Trump didn't explicitly name the women
item.itunes:summary: President Trump claimed the women "originally came from countries whose governments are a complete and total catastrophe". Also: Champs-Elysees clashes after Bastille Day parade, and Djokovic beats Federer in Wimbledon tennis epic.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Storm Barry begins to batter Louisiana
item.description: Storm Barry has made landfall in Louisiana, where officials have warned of potentially life-threatening floods. Also: UK says Iran tanker could be released 'with guarantees', and a powerful X-ray telescope is launched to map the cosmos.
item.itunes:subtitle: 100,000 households are already without power
item.itunes:summary: Storm Barry has made landfall in Louisiana, where officials have warned of potentially life-threatening floods. Also: UK says Iran tanker could be released 'with guarantees', and a powerful X-ray telescope is launched to map the cosmos.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Facebook facing '$5 billion' fine
item.description: The US Federal Trade Commission is said to have approved a penalty for Facebook over its handling of users personal data. President Trump's Labor Secretary resigns amid accusations he helped a billionaire sex offender secure a lenient sentence, and the trader in Togo who has an answer to the global fast fashion crisis
item.itunes:subtitle: The reported penalty follows a series of privacy scandals and data breaches
item.itunes:summary: The US Federal Trade Commission is said to have approved a penalty for Facebook over its handling of users personal data. President Trump's Labor Secretary resigns amid accusations he helped a billionaire sex offender secure a lenient sentence, and the trader in Togo who has an answer to the global fast fashion crisis
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Turkey: Arrival of Russian missile-defence system causes anxiety for US
item.description:
Turkey receives first parts of S-400 missile defence system despite opposition from US. Washington says Ankara cannot have both the S-400 and US F-35 fighter-jets.
Also, BBC investigation shows that Sudan's brutal crackdown on protestors was ordered from 'top level' of military, and should the world learn lessons from water-crisis in one of India's largest cities ?
item.itunes:subtitle: Turkey receives first parts of S-400 anti-aircraft system despite opposition from US
item.itunes:summary:
Turkey receives first parts of S-400 missile defence system despite opposition from US. Washington says Ankara cannot have both the S-400 and US F-35 fighter-jets.
Also, BBC investigation shows that Sudan's brutal crackdown on protestors was ordered from 'top level' of military, and should the world learn lessons from water-crisis in one of India's largest cities ?
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Trump retreats on census citizenship question
item.description: President Donald Trump will no longer pursue adding a question on citizenship to the 2020 US census questionnaire. Also: The UK has raised the threat to British shipping in Iranian waters to the highest level, and New Orleans braces for Tropical Storm Barry.
item.itunes:subtitle: President Trump backs down on adding citizenship question to 2020 census
item.itunes:summary: President Donald Trump will no longer pursue adding a question on citizenship to the 2020 US census questionnaire. Also: The UK has raised the threat to British shipping in Iranian waters to the highest level, and New Orleans braces for Tropical Storm Barry.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Strait of Hormuz: Iranian gunboats 'tried to intercept British ship'
item.description:
UK says one of its warships preventing Iranian vessels stopping a British oil-tanker.
Also, a BBC investigation into sex-scandal at heart of Afghan government, and scientists warn that even small amounts of sugary drinks may cause cancer.
item.itunes:subtitle: UK says one of its warships preventing Iranian vessels stopping a British oil-tanker
item.itunes:summary:
UK says one of its warships preventing Iranian vessels stopping a British oil-tanker.
Also, a BBC investigation into sex-scandal at heart of Afghan government, and scientists warn that even small amounts of sugary drinks may cause cancer.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Resignation of UK Ambassador to US is “black day for British diplomacy”
item.description: Politicians and civil servants have been reacting to the news that Sir Kim Darroch has stepped down. They’ve said the row over leaked memos is unprecedented. Also: the US women’s football team celebrates their World Cup win with a victory parade, and a school in the Netherlands faces a large fine because the children are too noisy.
item.itunes:subtitle: Sir Kim Darroch resigns after memos leaked criticising the Trump administration
item.itunes:summary: Politicians and civil servants have been reacting to the news that Sir Kim Darroch has stepped down. They’ve said the row over leaked memos is unprecedented. Also: the US women’s football team celebrates their World Cup win with a victory parade, and a school in the Netherlands faces a large fine because the children are too noisy.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: UK ambassador to Washington resigns after leak of memos critical of Trump
item.description: Sir Kim Darroch had described the Trump administration as inept and dysfunctional. Mr Trump responded by saying he'd no longer deal with him. Also: seagulls in Australia are found to be carrying several antibiotic resistant superbugs, and Spanish language hits now dominate the most watched music video chart on YouTube.
item.itunes:subtitle: Sir Kim Darroch said it was now impossible for him to carry out his role as he would like
item.itunes:summary: Sir Kim Darroch had described the Trump administration as inept and dysfunctional. Mr Trump responded by saying he'd no longer deal with him. Also: seagulls in Australia are found to be carrying several antibiotic resistant superbugs, and Spanish language hits now dominate the most watched music video chart on YouTube.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: UK foreign minister rebukes Trump
item.description: Donald Trump has been “disrespectful” towards the prime minister and the UK, says Jeremy Hunt. Also: Tory leadership rivals clash in TV debate, a Saudi Arabian princess goes on trial in France, and the end of the road for the VW Beetle.
item.itunes:subtitle: Trump 'disrespectful' to PM and UK, says Jeremy Hunt
item.itunes:summary: Donald Trump has been “disrespectful” towards the prime minister and the UK, says Jeremy Hunt. Also: Tory leadership rivals clash in TV debate, a Saudi Arabian princess goes on trial in France, and the end of the road for the VW Beetle.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Hong Kong leader says extradition bill 'is dead'
item.description: But Carrie Lam stops short of saying it has been fully withdrawn, and protesters have vowed to continue mass rallies. Also: Afghanistan talks agree 'roadmap to peace', and Egypt to sue Christie's auction house in London to retrieve Tutankhamun bust.
item.itunes:subtitle: But Carrie Lam stops short of saying it has been fully withdrawn
item.itunes:summary: But Carrie Lam stops short of saying it has been fully withdrawn, and protesters have vowed to continue mass rallies. Also: Afghanistan talks agree 'roadmap to peace', and Egypt to sue Christie's auction house in London to retrieve Tutankhamun bust.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Trump sharpens attack on UK ambassador over emails
item.description: The US president says "we will no longer deal" with the UK's ambassador in Washington, Sir Kim Darroch. Also the US financier Jeffrey Epstein is charged with sex trafficking minors, and a Nigerian opera performed in Pidgin English.
item.itunes:subtitle: Mr Trump also lashed out at the British PM Theresa May
item.itunes:summary: The US president says "we will no longer deal" with the UK's ambassador in Washington, Sir Kim Darroch. Also the US financier Jeffrey Epstein is charged with sex trafficking minors, and a Nigerian opera performed in Pidgin English.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: DRC warlord Bosco Ntaganda found guilty
item.description: The former Congolese rebel leader has been convicted of war crimes and crimes against humanity. Also: Amnesty International accuse the Philippine government of running a large-scale murdering enterprise connected to its so-called war on drugs, and the advanced robots moving into the Japanese workforce.
item.itunes:subtitle: Fighters loyal to Bosco Ntaganda carried out war crimes, including massacres
item.itunes:summary: The former Congolese rebel leader has been convicted of war crimes and crimes against humanity. Also: Amnesty International accuse the Philippine government of running a large-scale murdering enterprise connected to its so-called war on drugs, and the advanced robots moving into the Japanese workforce.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Centre-right regains power in Greece
item.description: The New Democracy party led by Kyriakos Mitsotakis wins the election with an absolute majority. Also: Donald Trump hits back after UK ambassador's leaked emails, and Jodrell Bank gains Unesco World Heritage status.
item.itunes:subtitle: The Greek PM Alexis Tsipras has admitted defeat
item.itunes:summary: The New Democracy party led by Kyriakos Mitsotakis wins the election with an absolute majority. Also: Donald Trump hits back after UK ambassador's leaked emails, and Jodrell Bank gains Unesco World Heritage status.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: France and Iran to look at conditions for talks
item.description: The French president Emmanuel Macron talks to his Iranian counterpart Hassan Rouhani by telephone in a bid to rescue the nuclear deal. Also: California quake damage 'not as bad as feared', and baby Archie christened at Windsor.
item.itunes:subtitle: Mr Rouhani calls on European countries to act urgently
item.itunes:summary: The French president Emmanuel Macron talks to his Iranian counterpart Hassan Rouhani by telephone in a bid to rescue the nuclear deal. Also: California quake damage 'not as bad as feared', and baby Archie christened at Windsor.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: UN welcomes the release of prisoners in Venezuela
item.description: The prisoners released included a high profile judge, Maria Lourdes Afiuni. Also: Trump vows to pursue citizenship census question, and the ancient city of Babylon becomes an Unesco World Heritage site.
item.itunes:subtitle: Venezuela described a UN report on alleged rights abuses as biased
item.itunes:summary: The prisoners released included a high profile judge, Maria Lourdes Afiuni. Also: Trump vows to pursue citizenship census question, and the ancient city of Babylon becomes an Unesco World Heritage site.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Iranian official threatens to seize British oil tanker
item.description:
Senior Teheran official issues threat after British troops' storming of Iranian vessel. British marines helped seize super-tanker on Thursday, after it was suspected of carrying oil to Syria, in breach of EU sanctions.
Also, how China is using schools to separate Uighur Muslim children from their culture and faith, and could global tree-planting help stop global warming ?
item.itunes:subtitle: Senior Teheran official issues threat after British troops' storming of Iranian vessel
item.itunes:summary:
Senior Teheran official issues threat after British troops' storming of Iranian vessel. British marines helped seize super-tanker on Thursday, after it was suspected of carrying oil to Syria, in breach of EU sanctions.
Also, how China is using schools to separate Uighur Muslim children from their culture and faith, and could global tree-planting help stop global warming ?
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: BBC evidence shows Uighur children in China being separated from their families
item.description: Government documents show that large numbers of state boarding schools have been built to house children as young as two. Also: Tehran has reacted with fury after British Royal Marines seized control of an Iranian supertanker carrying oil to Syria, and don't wake the neighbours! The cockerel that's been taken to court in France.
item.itunes:subtitle: Children as young as two are being kept in state boarding schools
item.itunes:summary: Government documents show that large numbers of state boarding schools have been built to house children as young as two. Also: Tehran has reacted with fury after British Royal Marines seized control of an Iranian supertanker carrying oil to Syria, and don't wake the neighbours! The cockerel that's been taken to court in France.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Libya: UN says 'migrants were fired upon after fleeing air strikes'
item.description:
UN has received reports that guards shot at migrants who tried to escape air-strikes. The attack on a detention-centre near Tripoli on Tuesday is believed to have killed at least 53 people.
Also, an oil-tanker bound for Syria is detained in Gibraltar by British marines, and a renowned scientist warns that the human race could soon become redundant.
item.itunes:subtitle: UN has received reports that guards shot at migrants who tried to escape air-strikes
item.itunes:summary:
UN has received reports that guards shot at migrants who tried to escape air-strikes. The attack on a detention-centre near Tripoli on Tuesday is believed to have killed at least 53 people.
Also, an oil-tanker bound for Syria is detained in Gibraltar by British marines, and a renowned scientist warns that the human race could soon become redundant.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Boeing pledges $100 million to support crash victims’ families
item.description: In the wake of two Boeing 737 Max crashes, the aerospace giant hopes it can repair its reputation, but families say the effort falls short. Also, the European Parliament elects David Sassoli as its new president, and Amsterdam considers a drastic change to its world-famous red light district.
item.itunes:subtitle: Aerospace giant still faces multiple lawsuits and demands for answers after 737 disasters
item.itunes:summary: In the wake of two Boeing 737 Max crashes, the aerospace giant hopes it can repair its reputation, but families say the effort falls short. Also, the European Parliament elects David Sassoli as its new president, and Amsterdam considers a drastic change to its world-famous red light district.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Libya: UN says attack on migrant camp could be 'war crime'
item.description:
UN speaks after air-strike kills more than 40 migrants at detention-centre near Tripoli. Libyan government blames attack on forces loyal to warlord General Khalifa Haftar, but they've denied this.
Also, why Rahul Gandhi has stepped down as head of India's Congress Party, and is there a close link between obesity and some common cancers ?
item.itunes:subtitle: UN speaks after air-strike kills more than 40 migrants at detention-centre near Tripoli
item.itunes:summary:
UN speaks after air-strike kills more than 40 migrants at detention-centre near Tripoli. Libyan government blames attack on forces loyal to warlord General Khalifa Haftar, but they've denied this.
Also, why Rahul Gandhi has stepped down as head of India's Congress Party, and is there a close link between obesity and some common cancers ?
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: EU announces nominees for top leadership positions
item.description: The European Council has agreed to a gender-balanced group of candidates after days of deadlocked negotiations. Also: The Russian navy says 14 sailors are dead after a submersible vessel caught fire, and women who survived torture in Syrian prisons tell their stories in a new London play.
item.itunes:subtitle: The European Council agrees on candidates after days of deadlock
item.itunes:summary: The European Council has agreed to a gender-balanced group of candidates after days of deadlocked negotiations. Also: The Russian navy says 14 sailors are dead after a submersible vessel caught fire, and women who survived torture in Syrian prisons tell their stories in a new London play.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: 2017: The Predictions Podcast
item.description: What is going to happen in 2017? President Marine Le Pen of France? The end of the Iran nuclear deal? Some of the BBC’s most senior correspondents forecast what might or might not happen during the next 12 months. Make your own predictions and join the discussion on the World Service Facebook page.
item.itunes:subtitle: The world in 2017, as predicted by BBC correspondents
item.itunes:summary: What is going to happen in 2017? President Marine Le Pen of France? The end of the Iran nuclear deal? Some of the BBC’s most senior correspondents forecast what might or might not happen during the next 12 months. Make your own predictions and join the discussion on the World Service Facebook page.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service
